questions.text: Which of the following is a polyene antifungal agent?
questions.solution:
Amphotericin B is a polyene antifungal.

Other polyene antifungals are:

  • Amphotericin B
  • Nystatin
  • Natamycin
  • Hamycin

Amphotericin B is the least toxic among polyenes and is used systemically for fungal infections. Nystatin and hamycin have high systemic toxicity and are used only for local and topical actions.

questions.text: What is the site of action of amphotericin B in fungi?
questions.solution:
The site of action of amphotericin B in fungi is the cell membrane.

Amphotericin B binds to the ergosterol in the cell membrane of fungi and forms pores or channels. They increase the permeability of the membrane to ions and cause leakage of cytosolic molecules. This leads to a loss of integrity of the cell membrane and causes fungicidal effects.

Recent evidence suggests that the amphotericin B sequesters ergosterol from lipid layers, much like a sponge, resulting in fungal cell death. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: Which formulation of amphotericin B has the highest risk of nephrotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Nephrotoxicity risk is highest with conventional amphotericin B. 

Conventional amphotericin B (C-AMB) is not a lipid-based formulation of amphotericin B. Amphotericin B is insoluble in water, hence C-AMB is formulated by complexing with bile salt deoxycholate to make it suitable for intravenous infusion.

Nephrotoxicity risk with amphotericin B formulations in decreasing order:

  • C-AMB > Amphotericin B lipid complex (ABLC) > Liposomal amphotericin B (L-AMB)
  • All lipid formulations of amphotericin B (ABLC, L-AMB, ABCD) are less nephrotoxic than conventional amphotericin B

Note: Amphotericin B colloidal dispersion (ABCD) has not been compared with other lipid-based formulations

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with periorbital swelling as shown below. She complains of significant visual impairment and a fungal etiology is suspected. What is the most appropriate drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of invasive mucormycosis in the form of orbital cellulitis. Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukaemia, lymphoma and other immunocompromised states. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 

Invasive mucormycosis has recently emerged as a life-threatening complication of COVID-19 in India. It is an opportunistic infection seen even in mild to moderate COVID patients with strong predisposing factors like hyperglycemia / uncontrolled diabetes. Diabetic patients receiving corticosteroids / immunosuppressants for COVID-19 treatment are exceptionally vulnerable to develop mucormycosis due to the risk of steroid-induced hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with mucormycosis is being treated with intravenous amphotericin B. Following administration of the drug, he starts experiencing chills, fever and dyspnea. These symptoms occur most frequently with which formulation?
questions.solution:
Development of fever and chills following intravenous administration is suggestive of infusion-related reactions which occur most frequently with amphotericin B colloidal dispersions.

Infusion-related adverse events are commonly seen with amphotericin B and it has been nicknamed 'shake and bake syndrome' due to the associated chills and fever.

Decreasing order of frequency of infusion-related reactions with amphotericin B formulations:
Amphotericin B colloidal dispersions (ABCD) > conventional amphotericin B (C-AMB) > amphotericin B lipid complex (ABLC) > liposomal amphotericin B (L-AMB).

questions.text: An immunocompromised patient with invasive mucormycosis is administered intravenous amphotericin B. Which frequently associated electrolyte disturbance would you be concerned about?
questions.solution:
Amphotericin B causes hypokalemia and hence potassium levels should be monitored in this patient.

Amphotericin B can cause renal tubular acidosis and renal wasting of K+ and Mg2+ leading to hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia during and several weeks after therapy. Potassium supplements are required in around one-third of patients on prolonged amphotericin B therapy.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with headache and nuchal stiffness. The CD4 count is 90 and CSF sample with India-ink staining shows the presence of encapsulated yeast cells. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the presence of encapsulated yeast cells in CSF with India ink staining are suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis. Amphotericin B plus flucytosine is the treatment of choice for this patient.

Cryptococcal meningitis is an AIDS-defining opportunistic fungal CNS infection that generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL.

In cryptococcal meningitis, amphotericin B combined with flucytosine is the current gold standard treatment in immunocompromised patients, especially in AIDS patients. 

In non-immunocompetent patients, the role of additional flucytosine along with amphotericin B is less clear. 

Oral fluconazole is used for consolidation and maintenance therapy after two weeks of induction therapy with amphotericin B.

questions.text: Identify the wrongly matched pair of antifungals with its mechanism of action:

choices.text: Flucytosine : Inhibits microtubule synthesis and thus hinders mitosis

questions.solution:
Flucytosine acts by inhibition of fungal DNA synthesis.

It is a pyrimidine antimetabolite. After uptake into fungal cells, fungal cytosine deaminase activates it to 5-fluorouracil, which is an anticancer drug. This is further converted into metabolites that inhibit thymidylate synthase which is necessary for DNA synthesis. Thus fungal DNA synthesis is inhibited. Mammalian cells are spared as they lack cytosine deaminase enzyme.

Flucytosine has clinically useful activity against (3C):

  • Cryptococcus
  • Candida species
  • Agents causing chromoblastomycosis

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A washerman presents with itchy, annular scaly plaques in the groin. He is prescribed with an antifungal that acts by interfering with mitosis. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Itchy annular plaques in the groin are suggestive of tinea cruris and the drug most likely given was griseofulvin which acts by interfering with fungal mitosis. 

Microtubule function is necessary for the formation of the mitotic spindle during cell division. Griseofulvin inhibits microtubule function and thereby disrupts mitotic spindle formation and inhibits cell division.

Tinea cruris is a dermatophytosis involving the groin and is also known as jock itch or dhobi's itch.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: To which of the following patients will you not prescribe griseofulvin?

choices.text: A middle aged man with tinea capitis

questions.solution:
Griseofulvin is not useful in the treatment of tinea versicolor. It is treated with topical azoles.

Tinea capitis, tinea cruris and tinea pedis are dermatophytoses. Griseofulvin is indicated only for dermatophytoses caused by species of Microsporum, Epidermophyton, and Trichophyton. It is considered the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children. It is reserved only for large topical tinea infections when topical therapy is inadequate.

Tinea versicolor is not a dermatophytosis. It is a superficial mycosis caused by lipophilic yeast Malassezia.

questions.text: Which of the following can cause contraceptive failure in a lady on oral contraceptive pills?
questions.solution:
Griseofulvin is a cytochrome enzyme inducer and can cause contraceptive failure when taken with oral contraceptive pills.

It induces hepatic CYP enzymes and can increase the metabolism of drugs. Warfarin metabolism is increased and the dose has to be adjusted according to the change in response. Estrogen metabolism is also increased thereby reducing the efficacy of low-dose estrogen-based oral contraceptives.

Note: Ketoconazole is a cytochrome enzyme inhibitor.

questions.text: Fungal cell wall synthesis is altered by which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Fungal cell wall synthesis is altered by caspofungin.

1,3-β-D glucan is an essential component of the fungal cell wall which maintains cell integrity. Echinocandin group of antifungals like caspofungin, anidulafungin, and micafungin acts by inhibiting the synthesis of 1,3-β-D-glucan and thereby weakens the fungal cell wall and increases the osmotic susceptibility.

Echinocandins are fungicidal against Candida species. They show fungistatic activity against Aspergillus species.

 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: What is the mechanism of triazoles?

choices.text: Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis
Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi

questions.solution:
Triazoles act by inhibition of ergosterol synthesis.

The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14-α-sterol demethylase and results in an impairment of conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol.

Azole antifungals are of two types:

  • Imidazoles - clotrimazole, ketoconazole, luliconazole
  • Triazoles - itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole and isavuconazole

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with coccidioidal meningitis. What is the drug of choice for the condition?
questions.solution:
Fluconazole is the drug of choice for coccidioidal meningitis caused by Coccidioides immitis because of better CSF penetration. 

Itraconazole is also effective in this condition but it is not the drug of choice. Amphotericin B is indicated in patients in whom triazoles have failed. 

Note: Amphotericin B is the drug of choice for initial treatment of cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans and fluconazole is used for maintenance therapy.

questions.text: A middle aged man presents with the condition shown in the image. Which of the following drugs can cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The image above depicts gynecomastia and can be caused by ketoconazole due to its antiandrogenic action.

Ketoconazole use results in various antiandrogenic effects. It decreases testosterone production and displaces testosterone from protein binding sites in plasma. It also decreases hydrocortisone production, especially at higher doses. Adverse effects that can occur are gynecomastia, loss of hair, libido, and oligozoospermia.

Fluconazole, itraconazole and voriconazole do not have antiandrogenic action.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for ketoconazole use?
questions.solution:
Ketoconazole is not indicated for use in Addison’s disease. 

It is a potent nonselective inhibitor of adrenal and gonadal steroidogenesis by inhibiting 17 α-hydroxylase enzymes which are involved in steroid hormone synthesis and it can hence worsen Addison's disease. However, this property also makes it useful in the treatment of Cushing’s syndrome.

Azoles interfere with leishmanial cell membrane biosynthesis and are therefore used in dermal leishmaniasis and kala-azar.

questions.text: While administering which of the following drugs will you counsel patients regarding transient visual and auditory hallucinations?
questions.solution:
Transient visual or auditory hallucinations are commonly seen with the use of intravenous voriconazole. These usually occur at night.

Other side effects of voriconazole are:

  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Prolonged QTc interval and increased risk of torsades de pointes
  • Anaphylactoid reaction when given intravenously

questions.text: Omeprazole dose is reduced when given along with voriconazole because of what action of the latter drug?
questions.solution:
Voriconazole is a strong inhibitor and substrate of CYP2C19. Concomitant omeprazole administration can result in increased omeprazole levels because of inhibition of metabolism.

In a patient on omeprazole 40 mg/day, the dose of omeprazole should be reduced to half when voriconazole is initiated. Additionally, higher levels of omeprazole can also interfere in voriconazole metabolism as omeprazole also inhibits CYP2C19.

questions.text: In a patient with athlete's foot, which keratolytic ointment would you prescribe to enhance treatment outcome?
questions.solution:
Salicylic acid is a keratolytic agent that can be prescribed to enhance the treatment outcome in patients with athlete's foot (i.e. tinea pedis).

Salicylic acid accelerates the desquamation of the stratum corneum. It is used in combination with a fungistatic drug called benzoic acid because eradication of infection is possible only if the infected stratum corneum is shed. This combination is called Whitfield's ointment and is used in the treatment of tinea pedis.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple annular itchy skin lesions with central clearing over his back.  You may prescribe any of the following except?
questions.solution:
Pruritic annular skin lesions with central clearing are suggestive of dermatophytosis for which amphotericin B must not be prescribed. Azoles, terbinafine, and griseofulvin are indicated for the treatment of dermatophytosis.

Dermatophytes are inhibited by amphotericin B but drug concentrations attained in the skin are very low and ineffective for the treatment of dermatophytosis.

The uses of amphotericin B are:

  • Treatment of choice in invasive mucormycosis
  • Candida albicans infection
  • Cryptococcus neoformans infection
  • Endemic mycosis

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used to treat candida infections?
questions.solution:
Griseofulvin is not used to treat candida infection. It is active against most dermatophytes but not against candida and other fungi causing deep mycosis.

Ketoconazole, nystatin, and amphotericin B are used in the treatment of candida infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about antifungal drugs?

choices.text: Amphotericin B is more effective parenterally
Ciclopirox olamine is effective in systemic mycoses
Fluconazole is effective orally as well as intravenously

questions.solution:
Ciclopirox olamine is a topical antifungal agent and is not effective in systemic mycoses.

Ciclopirox olamine is a broad spectrum fungicidal agent that acts by chelating trivalent metal ions which leads to inhibition of the metal-dependent enzyme that degrades free radicals. It is available as a nail lacquer formulation in the treatment of onychomycosis.

Option A: Amphotericin B is more effective parenterally for systemic mycoses. However, local or topical administration of amphotericin B drops is used in mycotic corneal ulcers. 

Option B: The absorption of griseofulvin is less when administered orally but microfining the drug particles increases the absorption.

Option D: Fluconazole can be administered orally as well as intravenously.

questions.text: Topical antifungal agents have no role in the treatment of patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Topical antifungal agents have no role in the treatment of subcutaneous mycoses like chromoblastomycosis. Itraconazole is the first-line antifungal indicated in this condition.

Topical antifungal agents are used in the treatment of:

  • Dermatophytosis
  • Candidiasis 
  • Piedra
  • Tinea versicolor
  • Tinea nigra 
  • Fungal keratitis

questions.text:
Which of the following antifungal drugs are used topically?
  1. Tolnaftate
  2. Flucytosine
  3. Butenafine
  4. Naftifine
  5. Clotrimazole
questions.solution:
Tolnaftate, butenafine, naftifine, and clotrimazole are used topically.

 Allylamine antifungals available for topical application are:

  • Terbinafine
  • Naftifine
  • Butenafine

Azoles that are used topically are:

  • Clotrimazole
  • Miconazole
  • Econazole

Tolnaftate is a topical synthetic antifungal agent. It distorts the mycelial growth of yeast-like fungi and molds. It is effective in the treatment of dermatomycosis and tinea.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with yellowish discolouration of toenails. The discolouration spread proximally as a streak in the nail and later, the entire nail separated from the nailbed. What is the mechanism of action of the drug of choice for her?

choices.text: Binding to ergosterol and altering membrane functions
Formation of pore  in cell membrane

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of tinea unguium or onychomycosis. The drug of choice is oral terbinafine which acts by inhibition of ergosterol synthesis. 

Terbinafine acts as a non-competitive inhibitor of squalene epoxidase, an early step enzyme in the synthesis of fungal ergosterol. This results in the accumulation of sterol squalene which is toxic to the organism.

The efficacy of terbinafine in onychomycosis is improved when combined with amorolfine 5% nail lacquer.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A farmer presented with complaints of redness and excessive watering from the right eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals the following finding. Microscopy of the corneal ulcer scraping shows branched septate hyphae. Which of the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Slit-lamp examination showing a corneal ulcer with satellite lesions and a thick hypopyon are suggestive of mycotic keratitis (fungal corneal ulcer) while branched septate hyphae are seen with Aspergillus and Fusarium. Natamycin 5% suspension is the drug of choice in this condition.

Treatment of fungal corneal ulcer:

  • Topical antifungals: Aspergillus and Fusarium infections are treated with natamycin, amphotericin B and voriconazole while Candida infections are treated with nystatin.
  • Systemic antifungals: Ketoconazole or voriconazole may be needed if there is a severe corneal ulcer, perforated ulcer, or suspicion of endophthalmitis.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

questions.text: Voriconazole is not effective against which of the following?
questions.solution:
Voriconazole is not effective against mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is treated by amphotericin B. Posaconazole can also be used. However, other azoles are not effective against this fungus.

Voriconazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of aspergillosis. It can also be used for Candida species (including glabrata and krusei), Scedosporium and Fusarium.
